skills.name: Warm Up
skills.tipsAndNotes:
####**Welcome to the Modern Greek course!**  
Of the 24 letters in the Greek alphabet, 13 are the same in appearance as the English alphabet when capitalized and use the same key on a QWERTY keyboard.   
** ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,  ,   ,  ,  ,  **.  

** ** is also familiar, but makes an [r] sound, and is on "R" key on a QWERTY (English) keyboard.  
So when you have conquered this skill you will be able to use over half of the Greek alphabet!  ![Duo9](https://imgur.com/5vv5BUm.png)  
NOTE: The Greek letter names are different to English names for the alphabet.   
####**Letters / Sounds in this skill**
|Greek|IPA, notes|
|:-:|:-|
| |[a] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%AC%CE%BD%CE%BD%CE%B1/f89146a82235ff95c9a9821019e83464) : Anna (as in "Ann**a**") : |
||[ai] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%B9/f94956ddec3cb77738f85560c648632b) : yes (as in "h**ai**l.")|
| |[v] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%B2%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF/d880e3687efaa6dc7444a3444cd56a3c) : vase (similar to "**v**ase")|
| |[e] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%B6%CE%B5%CE%B2%CF%81%CE%B1/6240f7b395a512a0b2f1c3161ec6093d) (as in "z**e**bra")|
||[i] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%B5%CE%AF%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%B9/fcd6006c78e44e5985e40f0006c960de) : it is/are (as in "mach**i**ne")  See  . |
| |[i] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CF%81%CF%8D%CE%B6%CE%B9/d79f9920d127240fdbfb5aa15b81efa1) : rice  (as in ""mach**i**ne, **I**carus")|
| |[k] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/carrot/bb9e9eddab0e996aa28f7242aca80aa2) : carrot (as in "**c**arrot")|
| |[m] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%BC%CE%B1%CE%BC%CE%AC/e146763b0072742fba3a9ef74c62470f) : mom (as in "**m**om")|
| |[n] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%BD%CE%B5%CF%81%CE%BF/a8ce20e3e1667d1af85922d1093078b1) : water, [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%B9/f94956ddec3cb77738f85560c648632b) : yes (as in "**n**ine")|
| |[o] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%B2%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF/d880e3687efaa6dc7444a3444cd56a3c) : vase (similar to " s**o**ft")|
| |[r] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CF%81%CF%8D%CE%B6%CE%B9/d79f9920d127240fdbfb5aa15b81efa1) : rice  (as in "**r**ice")  On the "R" key of a QWERTY keyboard.|
| |[t] [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/carrot/bb9e9eddab0e996aa28f7242aca80aa2) : carrot (as in "**t**rain) : [****](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CF%84%CF%81%CE%B5%CE%BD%CE%BF/b010e7f7dbd853290e5cbfae8194c0cf)|

You will need to use a Greek keyboard. 
####**Mini Introduction**
![](https://imgur.com/E073d44.png)  
ADDING THE GREEK ALPHABET TO YOUR KEYBOARD
Links to change your keyboard to use both Latin and Greek characters. : 
[Win.7,8](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/17424/windows-change-keyboard-layout) - 
[Win 10](https://www.conversationexchange.com/resources/keyboard-language.php?lg=en) - 
[Mac](http://www.wikihow.com/Change-the-Keyboard-Language-of-a-Mac)  
####**Accents**
Modern Greek has only ONE accent mark and it is only on vowels.   
i.e. **, , , , , , **.  
The accent goes on one of the three last syllables.    
Accents indicate where to put the emphasis when saying the word.  Most one syllable words do not have accents.   
Do note, there some cases where you DO need an accent as it makes a huge difference in the meaning.   
**To use the accent mark : press the semicolon key and then the vowel.**

**** (*like* mar**EE**a)  
****' (*like* kar**oo**to)  : carrot  

Capital letters have accents ONLY on the first letter of a word. 
****
Accents for capital letters are omitted for all other places..  
**/ ** : carrot  
** /  ** : vase.
####**Punctuation Marks**
The Period or full stop, the comma and the exclamation mark are the same as English.
The Greek **question mark** looks just like the English semicolon **;** and can be found on the **Q** key when you are on the Greek keyboard.  
####**Useful words**  
 : and  
 : yes  
 : it is  
####**Note**
Modern Greek is pronounced differently to the varieties of ancient Greek.  This course teaches modern  Greek.

##Genders
In Modern Greek there are three genders .

- neuter i.e. ** [](https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%B2%CE%AC%CE%B6%CE%BF/d880e3687efaa6dc7444a3444cd56a3c).** : the vase.      
- masculine   i.e **  (the title)
https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CF%84%CE%AF%CF%84%CE%BB%CE%BF%CF%82/c9fa9605b9e0f8ea24e8f8af03c55676
 
- feminine  i.e. **  **  (the chair)
https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%BA%CE%B1%CF%81%CE%AD%CE%BA%CE%BB%CE%B1/fae274ddae5ad2a206601cb0510074f7  


- H []  (the woman)
https://www.duolingo.com/dictionary/Greek/%CE%B3%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%BA%CE%B1/dc5bd84a804e585a60fb6ae15ffc2369)** : the woman 

As with many Indo-European languages, every noun has a gender.  For some nouns this is obvious, but for some it is less obvious.  

The gender is just a grammatical way to define how to use the **word** they DO NOT REFER TO THE ACTUAL PEOPLE OR OBJECTS.  And even inanimate objects can have different genders, and different articles are used for the different grammatical genders. 

  The endings of nouns often help to identify the gender.  Though there are many exceptions.

#Definite Articles#

Definite articles in Greek are equivalent to the English word ''the'', however, in Greek, they vary depending on the gender and number of the word that follows. .

Greek like Polish, Russian, and many other languages uses 3 grammatical genders to describe nouns. While English though, has the for every gender and number, Greek has six possible articles.

|Number and Gender in Nominative|Article|Example
|-|-|-|
|Singular masculine||  = the man|
|Plural masculine||  = the men|
|Singular feminine||  = the woman|
|Plural feminine||  = the women|
|Singular neuter||  = the child|
|Plural neuter||  = the children|

#Cases in Masculine and Feminine Gender#

Modern Greek has four cases in each number (Nominative, Genitive, Accusative, Vocative). The suffix shows the changes.

|Cases and Numbers|Example Masculine|Example Feminine|Example Neuter|
|-|-|-|-|
|Nominative singular|  = the man|  = the woman
|Genitive singular|  = of the man|  = of the woman|
|Accusative singular|  = the man|  = the woman|
|Vocative singular| = man| = woman|
|Nominative Plural|  = the men|  = the women|
|Genitive plural|  = of the men|  = of the women|
|Accusative Plural|  = the men|  = the women|
|Vocative Plural|=men|=women|

#Cases in Neuter Gender
|Cases and Numbers|Example Neuter 1|Example Neuter 2|
|-|-|-|
|Nominative singular|  = the child|  = the book
|Genitive singular|  = of the child|  = of the book|
|Accusative singular|  = the child|  = the book|
|Vocative singular| = child| = book|
|Nominative Plural|  = the children|  = the books|
|Genitive plural| = of the children|  = of the books|
|Accusative Plural|  = the children|  = the books|
|Vocative Plural| = children| = books

##INDEFINITE ARTICLES 
For the Indefinite articles (**A/AN/ONE** in English) Greek has 3 possible types according to the gender of the word that follows.

|Singular Masculine|Singular Feminine|Singular Neuter|
|-|-|-|
|NOMINATIVE: | or ||  a/one
|GENITIVE: | or ||   a/one
|ACCUSATIVE:  or | or ||   a/one
|VOCATIVE: ---|---|---|

Examples:

*    (masculine) = An / one elephant

*    (feminine) = A / one cat

*   (neuter) = A / one snake

The indefinite articles , ,  can be omitted when:

- The meaning of the sentence is general.

- The subject of the sentence can only be one.

- The number of subjects does not matter.

Examples:

The cat is an animal -    .

These two are not a couple -      .

Examples:
To **BE**

()  = I am

()  = you are (singular)

(, , )  = he, she or it is

()  = we are

()  = you are(plural) (or ****)

(, , )  =they are

Important note: the pronoun (,  ...is not always needed.)

|Pronouns|Example|
|-|-|
|1st person singular| = I|  = I eat|
|2nd person singular| = you|  = you eat|
|3rd person singular|// = he/she/it|  = he eats|
|1st person plural| = we|  = we eat|
|2nd person plural| = you|  = you eat|
|3rd person plural|/ = they (masculine/feminine)|  = they eat|

Note that **they** has two types. If it refers to a group all males or male and female or its gender composition is unknown, **** is used. If the group is composed of only females, **** is used instead.

Keep in mind that in Greek the personal pronoun (I, you etc) is not needed before the verb to define which person it is (as in English). 

The verb ending shows the person so for example:

****   I drink.

****  You drink  (singular)

****      He/She/It drinks.

**** &  We drink

****    You drink (plural

**** &  oral.  They drink

#Spelling Note#
* The word **** can also be written as ****. This can happen in all types of this word, just by replacing the letter **** with the ****.  Note: in listening exercises, you need to write what is said.  Usually, it is ****.

#HOW TO ADD THE GREEK ALPHABET TO YOUR KEYBOARD#

Here are some links to easily convert your keyboard to enable you to use both Latin & Greek characters as you need. We have found these easy to install and simple to use. If you have any other links please share them with the community.

For Windows

>https://billmounce.com/freegreekfont/unicode-windows

>https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/17424/windows-change-keyboard-layout

>https://www.conversationexchange.com/resources/keyboard-language.php?lg=en

For Mac

>http://www.wikihow.com/Change-the-Keyboard-Language-of-a-Mac

**HINT** Check the ***hover drop-down hints*** for ideas.  Remember they are like a dictionary and not all ideas may suit each sentence always us the top choice.


##Indefinite articles##

For the Indefinite articles (**a/an/one** in English) Greek has 3 possible types according to the gender of the word that follows.  

It's import to remember that:

`Gender refers to the grammatical pattern used by the word, it is not the actual gender of the person or thing.`  For example in Greek, "girl" is neuter, but "chair" is feminine.  So, be sure to learn the gender of each word from the start.

|Singular Masculine|Singular Feminine|Singular Neuter|
|-|-|-|
|NOMINATIVE: | or ||  a/one
|GENITIVE: | or ||   a/one
|ACCUSATIVE:  or | or ||   a/one
|VOCATIVE: ---|---|---|

Examples:

*    (masculine) = An / one elephant

*    (feminine) = A / one cat

*   (neuter) = A / one snake

##Indefinite Article Omission##

The indefinite articles , ,  can be omitted when:

- The meaning of the sentence is general.

- The subject of the sentence can only be one.

- The number of subjects does not matter.

Examples:

The cat is an animal -    .

These two are not a couple -      .

Do you have a car? -  ; 

I'm eating an orange -  . 


In plural numbers, Greek uses pronouns,  articles (like "some" in English). These words are:

*  Plural masculine:   **some/a few/a couple etc**

* Plural feminine: 

*  Plural neuter: 

|Plural Masculine|Plural Feminine|Plural Neuter|
|-|-|-|
|NOMINATIVE: |||    
|GENITIVE: |||
|ACCUSATIVE: |||
|VOCATIVE: |||

#Personal Pronouns#

|Person and Number|Pronouns|Example
|-|-|-|
|1st person singular| = I|  = I eat|
|2nd person singular| = you|  = you eat|
|3rd person singular|// = he/she/it|  = he eats|
|1st person plural| = we|  = we eat|
|2nd person plural| = you|  = you eat|
|3rd person plural|/ = they (masculine/feminine)|  = they eat|

Note that **they** has two types. If it refers to a group all males or male and female or its gender composition is unknown, **** is used. If the group is composed of only females, **** is used instead.

Keep in mind that in Greek the personal pronoun (I, you etc) is not needed before the verb to define which person it is (as in English). So for example instead of writing: ** **, you can write simply ****
Likewise ** ** can be written as ****

skills.name: Possessives
skills.tipsAndNotes:
####Possessives in Greek####

|Person|Possessive Pronoun (Single object owned)|Possessive Pronoun (Many objects owned)|English translation|
|-|-|-|-|
|1st person singular|(//) |(//) |My|
|2nd person singular|(//) |(//) |Your|
|3rd person singular (masculine)|(//) |(//) |His|
|3rd person singular (feminine)|(//) |(//) |Her|
|3rd person singular (neuter)|(//) |(//) |Its|
|1st person plural|(//) |(//) |Our|
|2nd person plural|(//) |(//) |Your|
|3rd person plural|(//) |(//) |Their|

EXAMPLES:                                                                    
  =My husband                                        
   = My own husband (emphatic).

**WHAT'S THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN , , ?**

**** is used if the owned object is of masculine gender:     =The man is mine.    

**** becomes **** when the owned object of masculine gender is in plural.                                                    
So,     =the men are mine.
               
**** is used if the owned object is of feminine gender: 
    =The woman is mine.                 

**** becomes **** when the owned object of feminine gender is in plural.                                                    
So,     =the women are mine.  
  
**** is used if the owned object is of neuter gender:     =The kid is mine.                                        

**** becomes **** when the owned object of neuter gender is in plural.                                                                                                                       
So,     =the children are mine.

**THE DOUBLE ACCENT RULE**                                            
When ,,,,,, comes after a word that is accented on the antepenultimate (third syllable from the end e.g. ****), then it is accented also on the last syllable. 

Example:                                                                                       
  =my car                                                         
  = her radio                                                    
  =his bag (no double accent here because the word  is not accented on the antepenult!)

skills.name: Food
skills.tipsAndNotes:
#Mini Introduction#

Greek cuisine is a Mediterranean cuisine, having common characteristics with the traditional cuisines of Italy, Turkey and the Balkans

Greek cuisine uses vegetables, olive oil, olives, wine, meat, fish, eggs and dairy products. Many food items are wrapped in Filo pastry such as ** ** | ko-to-pee-ta (chicken pie), ** ** | spa-na-ko-tee-ro-pee-ta (spinach and cheese pie), ** ** | kre-a-to-pee-ta (meat pie) etc.

Some very popular Greek foods and salads are ** ** | yee-ros (slices of pork roasted on a spit and served with sauce and garnishes, such as tomato and onions on pita bread), ** ** | su-vla-kee (grilled small pieces of meat, usually pork, but also chicken, served on the skewer for eating out of hand, or served as a sandwich wrapped in pita bread together with tomatoes, onions, tzatziki and ketchup; It is also called ** ** | ka-la-ma-kee mainly in Athens), ** ** | da-kos (Cretan salad consisting of a slice of bread or barley rusk / paximadi, topped with tomatoes and feta cheese), ** ** | fa-so-la-da (bean soup) and ** ** - mu-sa-kas (meat and eggplant casserole, topped with a savory custard which is then browned in the oven).

Popular beverages are **coffee, wine, beer and ouzo** ( anise-flavoured aperitif that is widely consumed in Greece and Cyprus).

skills.name: Plurals
skills.tipsAndNotes:
While in English, the plural is formed by adding 's' to the singular, in Modern Greek, to form the plural of nouns we have to take into account the gender of the word and change the singular suffix accordingly. Here are some examples for each gender:

#Masculine in Nominative#

**-** becomes ****, for example:   (one friend) becomes   (two friends)

**-** becomes ****,   (one pupil) becomes   (two pupils)

**-** becomes ****,   (one race) becomes   (two races)

**-** becomes ****,   (one grandfather) becomes    (two grandfathers)

**-** becomes ****,   (one coffee) becomes   (two coffees)

#Feminine in Nominative#

**-** becomes ****, for example:   (one daughter) becomes   (two daughters)

**** become **,**   (one country) becomes   (two countries)

**-** becomes  ****,   (one street) becomes   (two streets)

**-** becomes **-**,   (one fox) becomes   (two foxes)

#Neuter in Nominative#

**-** becomes ****,   (one gift) becomes   (two gifts)

**-** becomes ****,   (one child) becomes   (two children)

**-** becomes ****,   (one body) becomes   (two bodies)

**-** becomes ****,   (one forest) becomes   (two forests)

**-** becomes ****,   (one monster) becomes   (two monsters)

#ASTERISKS#
Note that these rules only apply to the Nominative case of nouns. The other three cases (Genitive, Accusative and Vocative) have their own suffixes.
Also, foreign words (such as , ) **are not** declined ie they stay the same no matter their case.

#HAVE AND BE AS AUXILIARY VERBS

##  

- The verb  (have)  is used as an auxiliary verb in Greek in Perfect Tenses:

 (have) +   (past participle) -> Present Perfect Simple ()

  (had) +   (past participle) ->  Past Perfect Simple ()

  (will have) +   (past participle) -> Future Perfect Simple ( )

##  

- he verb  (be) is used as an auxiliary verb in English, but there is no equivalent for it in Greek  in Continuous (Progressive) Tenses:

Present Continuous (same with Present Simple), : I am reading this book       (no auxiliary verb used.)

Past Continuous, : I was reading this book       (no auxiliary verb used.)

Future Continuous,  : I will be reading this book        (no auxiliary verb used.) 

##Have/Having  

The verb have, as well as its progressive form having  is in some cases used idiomatically in English, instead of other verbs. Such cases include pregnancy, food, medical conditions that last for a few moments (i.e. heart attacks), mental states or personal experiences, hosting events with a future intent etc. In Greek,  is not used in that way. 

Exp.
I am having/have lunch (instead of eating/eat)    . 
       
I am having a baby (instead of expecting)    /.
        
I am having/have fun   .
        
He is having a stroke.    . 
        
I am having a beer/drink     / .

A few exceptions to this rule are:
    
I have/I'm having a headache.   .
  
I'm having trouble with this.     . 

!Having can only be used as a participle.  

!Remember! Some Progressive tenses do not have directly equivalent tenses in greek.

In sentences with two objects, like "I give the juice to a friend", both objects will use the Accusative, and "to" will be translated as . If the next word is a form of the Greek "the",  will combine with it, yielding , ,  and other forms that you've seen or will see. There is nothing to fear because they are just +article.

Some examples:  
      = I give the juice to a friend.
     . = I give the salad to my wife.
      . = I don't give the chocolate to my brothers.
   
Two things to note about the Accusative:  
1. The article changes. As you've already seen in the "A Walk" skill,  becomes ,  becomes () and  becomes . Meanwhile, ,  and  don't change. In the plural,   becomes  , while   becomes   (  doesn't change).  
2. In a few cases, also the noun changes. Namely, masculine words lose the final -s, like  ->  in the example. In plural, masculine words that end in - like  will get the same - ending as the article:

###**Present Tense 1**:###

Greek Present Tense does not differentiate between simple (a one-time action: *we drink water*  = * *) and a:  continuous action: *we are drinking* = ** 

Verbs in Greek do not need to be preceded by the Personal Pronoun: ,  etc. (Similar to Portuguese and Spanish). The person is shown by the ending an the context: ***  >*I* want ice cream  (of course you can use the Personal Pronoun to clarify or for emphasis if you wish **   > *he* wants ice cream.

*The *INFINITIVE*: we use the first person of the verb with nothing in front: ** = to give

The use of the infinitive in sentences  e.g. He wants *to go* to the park. will be seen in a later unit.


*HOW TO FORM THE PRESENT TENSE*:  To the root form of the verb: e.g. from ** we use **  and add the ending for that verb.  So, for this type which is the most common you get:

**

Finally, note this form that will appear unusual for English speakers.
We only use...**** singular and  **** plural 
To say: *I like the puppy.* we will say: "*   *  This technically translates to: *"The puppy is liked by me,*"  Actually it simply means.  "I like the puppy."  For other persons, you simply use the necessary pronoun (, , , etc) .  "" does not change.  

*NEGATIVE FORMS*: Negatives are formed by adding  before the main verb.  *  .* > I do not (don't) drink coffee.  

*QUESTIONS* do not change their word order.  They just receive the GREEK question mark which looks just like a semicolon ; and change in intonation when spoken.  The Greek question mark can be found on the Q when you are using a Greek keyboard.

###1. Form of colors###
Colors are adjectives so in most cases the must agree with the noun in number, case and gender.    .  The green hats.  (Neuter, plural)  

###2   Form of colors###

###2. Use of colors###

Colors have the same gender, case and number as the noun they define. Usually, they are placed before it:

   . -  I have a white rabbit.

They can be put after the noun:

If they define a specific noun they are always placed before it:

###Demonstrative Adjective vs. Demonstrative Pronoun###

The **main difference** between demonstrative adjectives and demonstrative pronouns is that **demonstrative adjectives modify a noun** whereas **demonstrative pronouns replace a noun**.

- Demonstrative Adjective: Demonstrative Pronoun + definite article

** **     . - This woman is my mother.

** **    . - That house is ours.

 ** ** . - Take this coat.

- Demonstrative Pronoun: 

****    . - This (or She)  is my mother.

****    ! - That (or It) is our house!

 ****. - Take this/that.

skills.name: Personal objective pronouns
skills.tipsAndNotes:
Personal pronouns are also declined.                                 

The **nominative case** of the pronouns is used for the **subject** of the sentence, 

the **genitive case** for the **indirect object (the weak form only)** or to show **possession (the strong form of the third person only)**, 

the **accusative** for the **direct object** or for the **indirect object (+strong form only)**. 

Genitive and accusative cases also have weak forms, whose usage is described below.

|Case|First Person (Strong/Weak form)|Second Person (Strong/Weak form)|Third Person (Strong/Weak form)|
|-|-|-|-|
|Singular Nominative (Subject)|/-|/-|/-, /-, /-|
|Singular Genitive|/|/|/, /, /|
|Singular Accusative|/|/|/, /, /|
|Plural Nominative (Subject)|/-|/-|/-, /-, /-
|Plural Genitive|/|/|/ / /|
|Plural Accusative|/|/|/ /() /|


For the indirect object we use:
 **verb++strong accusative form** or **weak genitive form+verb**. 

So:    (more emphatic)= =he gives me /he gives to me.                                                                                  

For the direct object (accusative case) it's
 **Verb+strong form** or **weak form+verb**. 
So  =  (more emphatic)=He loves me.                                                           
If you want to use weak forms for both direct and indirect object in a sentence, the indirect comes before the direct and then the verb. 

So:   =He gives it to me.       

**Genitive Possession usage of the strong form**                
We have already learned the possessives (, , , , , ). When we want to be emphatic and demonstrative about the possession of some object, we can use the genitive strong from of the pronoun.   
For example:                                                                                            
  =His book.                                                             
  =This one's book.                                           
   =The man's book.                                    
    =This man's book.
                                                                      
**The difference between strong and weak forms: **                 
   =You read them a book.               
    =You read a book to them.                                                                                           
Also, strong forms are usually emphatic.

#IMPORTANT                                                                           
Weak genitive forms look exactly like the possessive pronouns. In order to differentiate them, *when in doubt*, we use the weak genitive form with an accent mark (,,,,,,).                                        

So,     . My child gives the ball.                                                 

     . =The child gives me the ball. (or The child gives the ball to me.)  *Note accent on *                                     

      . = My child gives me the ball.. (or My child gives the ball to me.)                          

**BUT** in  =He/She/It gives to me, the  is not accented because there is no room for confusion with the possessive pronoun.

skills.name: Genitive Case
skills.tipsAndNotes:
What English expresses using **possessives** or the **preposition**  **"of,"** Greek expresses using the GENITIVE CASE.

For example:
 	of the dog (genitive form)	
 	of the dogs (genitive form)

Example:
   =the dog's foot (literally, the foot of the dog)     
                                                                        
The genitive plural is easy because it's always formed with -****, and the article is always .

Example:                                                                                
   	the dogs' feet                                        
    the womens' feet                                
    the kids' feet

We use: ** or ** depending on the grammatical gender of the noun.  See some examples below.  
                                                                                              
The genitive singular is formed according to a greater variety of patterns, of which the most important are :                                                                            
 -         the man's/of the man                                                                 
 -        the dog's /of the dog                                                        
 -    the soldier's/of the soldier                                                  
 -     the woman's/of the woman                                                          
 -        the spider / of the spider                
 -       the girl / of the girl                       
 -      the book / of the book                         
 -    the meal/ of the meal

##Adjectives in Greek##
 
- Adjectives follow gender distinction: masculine, feminine, neuter. They decline as nouns and can be divided into groups according to the endings of the nominative singular.

- Adjectives belonging to a certain group decline the same way.

##Reflexive and Definite Pronouns##
 
###Reflexive Pronouns###
 
The reflexive pronouns ( ) are formed by the noun  (self) -accompanied by the article in the appropriate case- and the weak types of the personal pronouns (, , , , , ,  etc).

exp. **o**  **** (myself), ****  ****(theirselves)

* They are used when the action of the subject goes back to the subject itself.
 
* They are used in  the genitive and the accusative case ( and ).
 
* They can be used in the nominative case () emphatically.
 
exp.        ! - The only one you think about is yourself!
 
|Case|Singular|Plural|
|-|||

|Genitive|() |() |
|Accusative|() |() |
 
**Usage Examples:**
 
    - I look after myself. 
 
        . - You have to find time for yourself.
 
     . - She looked at herself in the mirror.
 
    . - Its a part of himself/him.
 
   . - Describe yourselves.
 
    ! - We will protect ourselves!
 
      . - They didnt try to defend themselves.
 
###Definite Pronouns###
 
The definite pronouns ( ) are:

*  the adjective , -, - accompanied by the article in the approriate case.
exp. ****  (himself), ****  (herself), **but**  ****  (I myself)

*  the adjective , -, - accompanied by the weak types of the personal pronouns (, , , , , ,  etc.)
exp.  **** ((by) myself),  **** ((by) ourselves)
 
They are used to make something or someone distinct from all the others of the same kind. 
 
(**Note: While these pronouns are considered to be reflexive in English, they are actually in two seperate categories in Greek. They do express reflexiveness.**)

skills.name: Verbs: Subjunctive Present
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##The Subjunctive Mood##
 
###In general###
 
The subjunctive mood () presents the action or the event as something **wanted or expected**.
 
- It indicates what the subject of the verb **wants, can, may, must do or is expecting to do**. 

- It is often used after verbs like **** (want), **** (can, may), **** (must), **** (hope), **** (think of), **** (wish) etc. . 

- It can be **Present** ( ), **Past** ( ) or **Present Perfect** ( ). 

- It is preceded by the particles **,  , , , , , , (),** etc.

- It is used to show **continuation** (resent Subjunctive) or **non-continuation** (Past Subjunctive) of the action and **not** the time aspect (present, past, future). 
 
##**Present Subjunctive**##
 
The subjunctive of Simple Present ( ) shows **continuation or repetition**. The action expressed by the verb is **ongoing** or **repeated**. 

It declares **urgency**, an **order** or a **prohibition***

*An order or a prohibition  with the particle () (also known as prohibitive/imperative subjunctive) .
 
 
###Formation###
 
The Present Subjunctive is formed by:

- The verb (active or passive) in the Simple Present form

- The particles **,  , , , , , **  etc. before the verb or

- The particle **()**, for prohibitive usage.

#Note: These are also the Tips from "Present 1"#

# - I am &  - I have#

For Modern Greek tenses and the conjugation of these two verbs see the notes in the 'Auxiliary Verbs' skill.https://incubator.duolingo.com/courses/el/en/editor/66ec9d611e21adc231449b799ae7aed1

###**Present Tense 1**:###

Greek Present Tense does not differentiate between simple (a one-time action: *we drink water*  = * *) and a:  continuous action: *we are drinking* = ** 

Verbs in Greek do not need to be preceded by the Personal Pronoun: ,  etc. (Similar to Portuguese and Spanish). The person is shown by the ending an the context: ***  >*I* want ice cream  (of course you can use the Personal Pronoun to clarify or for emphasis if you wish **   > *he* wants ice cream.

*The *INFINITIVE*: we use the first person of the verb with nothing in front: ** = to give

The use of the infinitive in sentences  e.g. He wants *to go* to the park. will be seen in a later unit.


*HOW TO FORM THE PRESENT TENSE*:  To the root form of the verb: e.g. from ** we use **  and add the ending for that verb.  So, for this type which is the most common you get:   

####Singular####

|Person|Greek|English|
|-|||

|Second person|() |You give|

####Plural

|Person|Greek|English|
|-|||
|First person|() |We give|
|Second person|() |You give|
|Third person|(//) /|They give|

Note the two forms for *YOU*:  ** = *you give* >singular and ** = *you give*  plural and formal.

**

Finally, note this form that will appear unusual for English speakers.

To say: *I like the puppy.* we will say: "*   *  This technically translates to: *"The puppy is liked by me,*"  Actually it simply means.  "I like the puppy."  For other persons you simply use the necessary pronoun (, ,  etc) .  "" does not change.  

*NEGATIVE FORMS*: Negatives are formed by adding  before the main verb.  *  .* > I do not (don't) drink coffee.  

*QUESTIONS* do not change their word order.  They just receive the GREEK question mark which looks just like a semicolon ; and change in intonation when spoken.  The Greek question mark can be found on the Q when you are using a Greek keyboard.  

*CONTRACTING VERBS* * *                                                                               
There are some verbs that can be conjugated in multiple ways. Verbs ending in - fall in this category. (such as -, -, -)

skills.name: Imperative (Active Voice)
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##The Imperative Mood##

###In general###

The imperative mood () expresses command.

- It is used in the 2nd person singular and plural.
 
- It can be Present ( ), Past ( ) and Present Perfect* ( )

*not included in the course.

###Present Imperative###

Present Imperative expresses duration or repetition of the action. 

####Formation####

The Present Imperative is formed by:

- The stem of the verb it its **Simple Present form** 

- The endings **/, /, or /** after the stem of the verb

- The particle **() + the subjunctive form of the verb (in 2nd singular or plural), for prohibitive usage.**


**Formation Example:**

- For verbs that end in **-**, use the endings **-, -**.

- For verbs that end in **-**, use the endings **-, -** or **-, **.

For the verb : +,  + -> , 

For the verb : -, - -> , 

For the verb : -, - -> , 


**Usage Examples:**

/  . - Write faster.

/  . - Speak clearer.

/  . - Eat more slowly.



###Past Imperative###

Past Imperative expresses non-continuation. The action is not ongoing, or  the speaker is not interested in its duration. 

####Formation####

The Past Imperative is formed by:

- The stem of the verb it its **Simple Past form** 

- The endings **-/- or -/, - or /-/-/-**, after the stem of the verb


**Formation Example:**

- For verbs that end in **-**, use the endings **-/-, -**.

- For verbs that end in **-**, use the endings **-,/-/-/-/-**.

For the verb : -,  - -> , 

For the verb : -, - -> , 

For the verb : -, - -> , 

For the verb : -, - -> , 

For the verb : -/-, - -> /, 

For the verb : -, - ->, 

**Usage Examples:**

/ ! - Talk to me!

///  ,  . - Go to sleep, its late.

/ , ! - Wait for me, Im coming!

/     /. - Write your phone number (down).

skills.name: Subjunctive Aorist
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##The Subjunctive mood##

###In general###

The subjunctive mood () presents the action or the event as something wanted or expected. 

- It indicates what the subject of the verb wants, can, may, must do or is expecting to do.  And may be similar to the English Infinitive.
 
- It is often used after verbs like **** (want), **** (can, may), **** (must), **** (hope), **** (think of), **** (wish) etc. .
 
- It can be **Present** ( ), **Past** ( A) and **Present Perfect** ( ). 

- It is preceded by the particles **,  , , , , , , ()**, etc.

- It is used to show **continuation** (resent Subjunctive) or **non-continuation** (Past Subjunctive) of the action and **not** the time aspect (present, past, future). 

##Past Subjunctive##

The subjunctive of the Simple Past ( ) expresses **non-continuation**. he action expressed by the verb is **not ongoing** or the speaker is not interested in the duration of the action. 

###Formation###

The Past Subjunctive (for active verbs) is formed by:

- The stem of the active verb in the **Simple Past** form
 
- The endings **-, -, -, -, -, -** after the stem of the verb

- The particles **,  , , , , , **  etc. before the verb or

- The particle **(), for prohibitive usage.**

**Formation Example:**

For the verb  (read): ** + - + - ->  **

**!If the verb gets an extra  in its simple past form, make sure not to include it.**

For the verb  (write): ** + - + - ->  **

skills.tipsAndNotes:
##Present Participles of Active Voice##


Present participles (M  ) can either be used as:

- **Adverbs** or

- **Adjectives**

###Adverbial Participles###

* Are forms of active verbs that do not decline 
* Have an adverbial function and can indicate time, manner, cause, condition etc. (with manner being the most common one.)
* Are formed by the present stem of the active verb and the endings - or -

####**Formation:**####

* **Verbs that end in an accented -, form the participle in -.**

-**** - **** (singing)

-**** - **** (trying)

-**** - **** (walking)

-**** - **** (asking)

-**** - **** (speaking)

-**** - **** (flying)

-**** - **** (laughing)

-**** - **** (looking back, reminiscing)

-**** - **** (searching for) 

**Usage examples:**
       
  ,     - While walking on the street, I saw your mother. 

  ,        - The swallows travel, flying from one country to another.
        
,    - When you ask/By asking, you always learn more.
         
   - She looked at him, smiling.

* **Verbs that end in a non accented -, form the participle in -.**

-**** - **** (running)

-**** - **** (playing)

-**** - **** (doing)

-**** - **** (getting up)

-**** - **** (getting down)

-**** - **** (going)

-**** - **** (searching/looking for)

-**** - **** (reading)

**** - **** (writing) 
 
**Usage Examples:**

    . - She left the house running.
       
   . - I relax (while) listening to classical music.
 
     - We spent the night watching films. 

   - lit. Seeing and doing (Seeing how things turn out, and then acting accordingly.)


!The participle **** (being) is the participle of the verb  (be). **Its an exception**, as it doesnt belong to any of the two categories mentioned above. 

,     . - He returned, being readier than ever.
       
  ,   . - Being an experienced lawyer, he won the trial.

 ,     . - (By) Being optimistic, you always hope for the best.
      
  ,    - He didnt drink alcohol, as hes still an underage. 



###Adjectival Participles###

* Are forms of active verbs that decline

* Have an adjectival function

They could be:

- Oxytone (, -, -, ,-, -)

Note: Proparoxytone -> Accented on the third-to-last syllable/antepenult

Paroxytone -> Accented on the second-to-last syllable/penult
          
Oxytone -> Accented on the last syllable/ultima
 
###The Vocative Case###
 
The vocative case is the case for a noun or adjective used:

**(1)** for identifying a person, animal, object, etc. being addressed, 

**(2)** for making exclamatory remarks, or 

**(3)** in apposition to another vocative. 
 
A vocative is **grammatically independent** from the sentence with which it is placed. It does **not** serve the grammatical role of a subject, direct object or any other part of the actual sentence structure.
 
exp. I dont know Mary -      ( as a direct object of the verb .)

**BUT** I don't know, Mary -  , . (M as a vocative expression that indicates the party being addressed)
 
**For masculine singular:**
 
- Proparoxytone words that end in -**** form vocative in -**** 

exp. **** - ****, **** - ****,  **** -****, **** - **** 

!First and last names follow this rule. 

exp. **** - A****, **** - **** 
 
- Paroxytone words that end in -**** form vocative in -****

exp. **** - ****, **** - ****, ****- ****

!First and last names do not follow this rule, and form vocative in -**o**.

exp. **** - ****, **** - ****, **** - 
 
- Oxytone words that end in -**** form vocative in -****

exp. **** - ****, **** - ****, **** - ****, **** - **** 

!First and last names do not follow this rule, and form vocative in -**o**.
 
- Paroxytone words that end in -**** form vocative in -**** or -**** (in formal occasions)

exp. ****-****, ***but*** **** - ****, **** -****

!First and last names do not follow this rule, and form vocative in -****.

exp. **** - ****, **** - ****
 
- xytone words ending in -**** form vocative in -**** or -**** (in formal occasions)

exp. ****-****, ***but*** **** - ****, **** - ****,  ****- ****

!First and last names do not follow this rule, and form vocative in -****.
 
(**Note: The vocative in - is formal, and commonly used in formal occasions.**)

- Paroxytone words that end in -**** form vocative in -****
exp. **** - ****, ****- **** 

!First and last names follow this rule.

exp. **** - ****, **** - ****
 
**For masculine plural: Vocative is the same as Nominative.**

**For feminine singular and plural : Vocative is the same as Nominative.**

**For neuter singular and plural: Vocative is the same as Nominative.**
 
**Usage Examples:**

 ! - Yes, sir!

  ; - Where are you going, young man?

,    - Professor, I have a question.

  ! - Oh my God!

 ,   - Good try, my friend.

skills.name: Present Passive
skills.tipsAndNotes:
The Passive Voice is not used in Greek as commonly as in other languages. It is mainly used when we want to emphasize on the action.

# (Present Simple / Present Continuous)#

**  (Active Voice)**

    - I write a book / I am writing a book

**  (Passive Voice)**

   ( ) - A book is written (by me) / A book is being written (by me)


# (Past Continuous)#


**  (Active Voice)**

    - I was writing a book

**  (Passive Voice)**

   ( ) - A book was being written (by me)
 
# (Past Simple)#

**  (Active Voice)**

    - I wrote a book


** 	(Passive Voice)**

   ( ) - A book was written (by me)

 
#  (Future Continuous)#

**  (Active Voice)**

     - I will be writing a book

**  (Passive Voice)**

    ( ) - A book will being written (by me)

#  - Future Simple#

**  (Active Voice)**

     - I will write a book

** 	(Passive Voice)**

    ( ) - A book will be written (by me)
 
 
# (Present Perfect)#

**  (Active Voice)**

     - I have written a book

**  (Passive Voice)**

    ( ) - A book has been written (by me)
 
# (Past perfect)#

**  (Active Voice)**

     - I had written a book.

** 	(Passive Voice)**

    ( ) - A book had been written (by me)
 
#  (Future Perfect)#

**  (Active Voice)**

      - I will have written a book	

** 	(Passive Voice)**

     ( ) - A book will have been written (by me)
 
 
#TIPS#

1. Verbs in Passive voice have - ending e.g  - I am written,  - I am heard e.t.c.
2. The object of the active verb is the subject of the passive verb.

skills.name: Pronouns relative
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##**Greek Relative Pronouns**##
As relative elements ( ) you can use:  
(1) he pronoun ** ,  ,  **.  
(2) The conjunction **** (does not decline.)  
A Greek relative pronoun (** **)  **agrees** with the **number** and **gender** of its antecedent, that is, with the noun to which it refers.  

**! In English**, the relative pronoun **is gender indefinite**.    
  
**How  to use:**  form of the article (**,,**) + form of the pronoun **, , **.  

**!Remember!** This pronoun **is not** the interrogative pronoun, which is used in a question. Rather, the relative pronoun is usually translated as the first word of a dependent clause called a relative clause.  

**!Remember!** A clause has a subject and verb, like a sentence, but a dependent clause cannot function by itself as a sentence, because the completion of its thought depends on the rest of the sentence. And this also means the main subject and main verb of the sentence will never be found in the relative clause.

skills.name: Adjectives-comparison
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##Adjective Comparison Degrees##

Adjectives have three degrees of comparison: **Positive (), Comparative () and Superlative ().**

The **Positive** degree ( ) is the base form of the adjective, that simply expresses a quality. 

The **Comparative** degree  ( ) is used to express **a higher degree of some quality**. It is formed

- in one word, with the **adjective stem + the comparative suffix - (m.), - (fem.), - (neut.)***,
 
e.g.  -> -****=more beautiful,  -> -****=taller,  -> -****=deeper

- in more than one word, with ** (more) + adjective**

e.g.  -> **** =more beautiful,  -> **** =taller, -> **** =deeper

*Adjectives ending in **-, -, -** have the superlative suffix **-, -, -.**

e.g.  -> ****=more popular,  -> ****=more clear

**In Greek, there are two kinds of superlative degrees**.  
                       
**The Relative Superlative** ( ), is used to express that a noun has **the highest degree of some quality (than every other similar object)**. It is formed

- in one word, with the **definite article // (the) + the comparative form of the adjective**

e.g.  -> **** =the most beautiful,  -> **** =the smallest,  -> **** =the longest

- in more than one word, with the **definite article // +  (the most) + adjective**
    
e.g.  -> ** ** =the most beautiful,  -> ** ** =the smallest,  -> ** ** =the longest
                                                                              
**The Absolute Superlative ( )** is used to declare that the noun has **a higher degree of some quality (without comparing to everything else)**. It is formed 

- in one word, with the **adjective stem +  the superlative suffix - (m,), - (fem.), - (neut.)***,

e.g.  -> ****=very fast,  -> ****=very young,  -> ****=very nice
 
- in more than one word, with ** (very) + adjective**.

e.g.   -> **** =very big,  -> **** =very young,  -> **** = very deep

*Adjectives ending in **-, -, -** have the superlative suffix **-, -, -.**

e.g.  -> ****=very popular,  -> ****=very clear,  ->****=very obvious

##Past Participles of Passive Voice##

Past Participles ( ):

skills.name: Adverbs Comparison
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##Adverb Comparison Degrees##

Adverbs, just like adjectives, have three degrees of comparison: Positive (), Comparative () and Superlative ().

There are two ways to form the Comparative and the Superlative: in one word, () and in more than one word ().

To form the **Comparative** degree:

- in one word, the comparative suffix* is added. 

**-** -> **-** 

**-** -> -**** 


- in more than one word, the adverb is preceded by ****.

**-** -> **** ****

**-** -> **** ****  


To form the **Superlative** degree:

- in one word, the superlative suffix* is added.

**** -> ****

**** -> -****

- in more than one word, the adverb is preceded by ****.

**** -> **** ****

**** -> **** ****


*About the suffixes:

Adverbs derived from adjectives ending in -, end in - (e.g. -, -).

Adverbs derived from adjectives ending in -, end in - (e.g -, -)

**These adverbs have the comparative ending - and the superlative ending  -.**

Adverbs that derive from adjectives ending in -, end in - (e.g. -, -)

**These adverbs have the comparative ending - and the superlative ending -.**

###Nature###

The word for nature  in Greek is  .  As in English it is used not only for the natural world (landscapes, the moon, the stars etc) but also for characteristics of people and objects.  

Also, note that the definite article  usually accompanies the word  whereas we do not use it in English except for phrases:

#Primary and Secondary Education in Greece and Cyprus#

** ** and  **** are the male and female teachers of the Elementary/Primary school, called **** in Greek. Students call their teachers by their first name but with the honorific **** (=Mrs) or **** (=Mr) . Unmarried female teachers can be also called **** (Miss).  The **** usually finishes at 12 or 1 pm but some students stay later at the **** (=full day school).  Here they have **** (=lunch) and do their homework (****).  


After the ****, students go to the **** 
(= junior high/middle school) for 3 years (not to be confused with **** which is a gym or gymnasium in English). At the age of 15, students  choose between ** ** (=general high school) and ** ** (=technical high school).   Here they are taught by:   or  .

#Higher Education#

Upon completion of the **** (=high school), most of them continue on to ** ** (=higher education).  Here the teachers have the same titles as in secondary education ** ** or ** **. (=professors) .  

There are three categories of higher education: 1) **/ ** (=public/private universities), 

2) ** ** or simpler **** (=technological institutes) 

3) ** ** (=private schools for higher education).



Students ** ** (=take exams) and get reports **** each **** (=semester).

When students take exams, there is a wish at the bottom of the sheet, reading ** ** (=Good luck). We wish you ** '** for this skill too ;)

skills.name: Subjunctive Passive
skills.tipsAndNotes:
##The Subjunctive Mood##
 
###In general###
 
The subjunctive mood () presents the action or the event as something **wanted or expected**.
 
- It indicates what the subject of the verb **wants, can, may, must do or is expecting to do**. 

- It is often used after verbs like **** (want), **** (can, may), **** (must), **** (hope), **** (think of), **** (wish) etc. . 

- It can be **Present** ( ), **Past** ( ) or **Present Perfect** ( ). 

- It is preceded by the particles **,  , , , , , , (),** etc.

- It is used to show **continuation** (resent Subjunctive) or **non-continuation** (Past Subjunctive) of the action and **not** the time aspect (present, past, future). 


##Present Subjunctive##

The subjunctive of Simple Present ( ) shows continuation or repetition. The action expressed by the verb is ongoing or repeated. 
It declares urgency, an order or a prohibition*

*An order or a prohibition  with the particle () (also known as prohibitive/imperative subjunctive) .


###Formation###

The Present Subjunctive is formed with:

- The verb (active or passive) in the **Simple Present** form

- The particles **,  , , , , , **  etc. before the verb or

- The particle **(), for prohibitive usage.**

   . - Dont think so negatively.

     - We dont want to stand still.

  ,     . - If I remember correctly,  put them in the drawer.  


##Past Subjunctive##

The subjunctive of the Simple Past ( ) expresses **non-continuation**. he action expressed by the verb is **not ongoing** or the speaker is not interested in the duration of the action. 


###Formation###

The Past Subjunctive (for passive verbs) is formed with:

- The stem of the passive verb in the **Simple Past** form
 
- The endings **-/, -/, -/, -/, -/, -/** after the stem of the verb

- The particles **,  , , , , , **  etc. before the verb or

- The particle **(), for prohibitive usage.**

skills.tipsAndNotes:
+imperfect results in "would". 

I would like= ,                                                                            
You would do it=  ,       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  He would love it!=  !,  
                                                                                                                 If the day was good, we would run=    ,  etc etc.       
    ;=Could you help me?     

We use +imperfect to form the polite request with "would" or the present conditional that has the same uses as in English.                                                                    
So,     =I would like a cup of tea (now)                                                                                                                    
  ,     =If I were tired, I would like a cup of tea. (conditional)                         

 + imperfect is ***not*** the same as using the future continuous!                                                                                                 
  ,     =After reading, I will want a cup of tea (I know beforehand that after reading I will definitely want a cup of tea)

It should also be noted that some cities have a holiday on the Celebration of the Patron Saint of that city.

A Name day is the Holiday of the Saint whose name you bear.  That means that you celebrate your name day and get gifts and treat friends and relatives to sweets etc. Sometimes this holiday is more important than your birthday.

Birthdays and Anniversaries are also celebrated.
